Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a fluorescence microscope to serve as a regional resource for dynamic, live-specimen imaging research and education
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to James Madison University (JMU) to fund the acquisition of an automated, fluorescence microscope system for dynamic, live-specimen imaging to advance research and education at JMU and in the surrounding region in Virginia. This instrumentation will expand the scope of research in multiple departments at JMU and in neighboring institutions by enabling faculty and students to study the dynamics of molecules, cells, and tissues. JMU and most of its neighboring colleges are primarily undergraduate institutions and are committed to engaging students in learning through faculty-mentored research. Indeed, students are responsible for over 95% of the total research use of our core microscopy facility. The new microscope system will provide these students with exposure to live imaging and multi-fluorescence technologies unavailable elsewhere in our region, and will expand the facility's ability to increase research opportunities for undergraduates. This instrumentation will also enhance formal upper-division courses such as Human Histology and Environmental Microbiology by providing students with practical training in light microscopy techniques. Moreover, in an effort to expand our impact on undergraduate research training, we will work with Bridgewater College's Biology Department (a neighboring, small liberal arts college) to provide access for their upper-division courses. Finally, this microscope system will support science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) education in the northern Shenandoah Valley region by enhancing the JMU Biology Department's local elementary school outreach program. This program provides K-5 classes with the kinds of science enrichment experiences known to pique early interest in science (but often only accessible to select populations) to all students regardless of academic readiness, language and cultural barriers, and socioeconomic status. This state-of-the-art instrument will be integrated into 5th grade learning modules focusing on the components and dynamic nature of cells.

The new fluorescence microscope system will open new investigative avenues for researchers at JMU and in the region by enabling the study of dynamic processes at multiple levels of biological organization-from molecular assemblies to entire organisms-and by accommodating multi-fluorescent-label imaging with a broader diversity of fluorescent probes. It will advance the research and training programs of at least 16 faculty members from three institutions and multiple STEM fields including biology, kinesiology, regenerative medicine, mathematics, engineering and science education. Projects that will be substantially impacted include: cornea tissue wound healing and regeneration; using molecular and mathematical tools to investigate cell- and organism-level responses to protein mis-folding (a component of many neurodegenerative diseases) in nematodes; genome reorganization during crustacean development; the relationship between stress and feeding behavior in mammals; and the role of endocrine signaling in the control of sexual signal production in snakes. The new instrumentation will also impact research in JMU's Kinesiology and Engineering departments, among others, as well as at neighboring institutions such as Bridgewater College, Eastern Mennonite University and the Marion DuPont Equine Medical Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this proposal was to acquire a fluorescence light microscope system to enable multi-dimensional imaging, including acquiring images over time, in 3D, and over large areas at high resolution. The microscope was intended to accommodate a broad range of uses, thereby, 1) meeting the current imaging needs of James Madison University (JMU) faculty and broadening the scope of their future research; 2) promoting research training of JMU undergraduate and masters students interested in scientific research and applied fields, 3) enhancing existing courses to provide practical training in light microscopy techniques; and 4) fostering interdisciplinary and collaborative research between JMU departments and institutions across the Northern Shenandoah Valley.

Impact on Research: Since the microscope's installation in March 2018, it has become the most heavily used system in the light microscopy core facility, consistently logging hundreds of hours of use in each of the past two years. The microscope has been used by 47 different users from 15 different lab groups that study a wide range of topics, including cancer biology, neurobiology, animal development and evolution, and malaria. Research conducted on this microscope has led to over 30 conference presentations, four funded grants, and three scientific publications that have advanced our understanding of aural disorders and autism spectrum disorders.

Impact on Student Research Training: Students have been integral to the research advancements mentioned above. 41 of the 47 users were students (2 high school, 2 masters, and 37 undergraduate; 60% female) and these students were responsible for the vast majority of the microscope's use. Indeed, nearly all of the aforementioned presentations and publications were authored or co-authored by students. Most undergraduate (not to mention, high school) students never have the opportunity to use such a sophisticated instrument independently. The advanced training received by these students has both broadened their education and helped equip them for careers in research and medicine. 

Impact on Microscopy Education: In conjunction with acquiring the microscope system, we developed a new curriculum for training students to be independent users of the advanced microscopes in the core facility. Our new curriculum focused not only on providing them with practical expertise, but also a theoretical understanding of the technique they were using. This new curriculum is currently being scientifically evaluated to determine its effectiveness and to identify areas of improvement. In addition to research students, the new microscope has been used in three courses: Light Microscopy, Animal Development, and Human Histology. Finally, the microscope has been involved in numerous middle-school and high-school outreach activities conducted by the microscopy core facility that give young students exposure to STEM research.

Impact on Interdisciplinary and Inter-institutional Work: The user-base of the microscope system has broadened over the past three years. We are seeing increasing interdisciplinary and inter-institutional use as its specialized capabilities enable new research directions and collaborations with researchers in the area. A collaboration between a JMU faculty member and a researcher at George Washington University focuses on understanding the genomes of freshwater zooplankton. Another collaboration between a JMU chemistry professor, a JMU engineering professor, and a Virginia Commonwealth University bioengineering professor focuses on the physical interactions between cells in tissues. In addition, the microscope system is now being used by a member of a neighboring institution, Eastern Mennonite University.
